channel.title: Comments on: Thoughts on User Groups, Speaking, and Paying It Forward
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Jes Schultz Borland (grrlgeek)
item.dc:creator: Jes Schultz Borland (grrlgeek)
item.description: @Justin - Speaking is the best! We don't have a mailing list, so we rely on the face-to-face time at meetings. Personally, I'd never volunteer anyone else to speak for something. Public speaking is such a deep-seated fear for so many people that I don't want anyone mad at me!
item.content:encoded: @Justin – Speaking is the best! We don’t have a mailing list, so we rely on the face-to-face time at meetings. Personally, I’d never volunteer anyone else to speak for something. Public speaking is such a deep-seated fear for so many people that I don’t want anyone mad at me!

item.title: By: Steve Hughes (DataOnWheels)
item.dc:creator: Steve Hughes (DataOnWheels)
item.description: This is so true. I work with the Minnesota SQL Server User Group (MNPASS) and we have seen speakes come up through our group over the years including Mr. Strate (@StrateSQL). We have since started our local presenter offering which we have a lesser experienced presenter use 15-30 minutes to share with the group. More users talking about what they do is AWESOME!
item.content:encoded: This is so true. I work with the Minnesota SQL Server User Group (MNPASS) and we have seen speakes come up through our group over the years including Mr. Strate (@StrateSQL). We have since started our local presenter offering which we have a lesser experienced presenter use 15-30 minutes to share with the group. More users talking about what they do is AWESOME!

item.title: By: Justin Dearing
item.dc:creator: Justin Dearing
item.description: Speaking is awesome. I got my start at LIPHP when a fellow member publicly volunteered me to speak on the mailing list. Have you ever considered actively soliciting a new speaker in that manner?
item.content:encoded: Speaking is awesome. I got my start at LIPHP when a fellow member publicly volunteered me to speak on the mailing list. Have you ever considered actively soliciting a new speaker in that manner?
